text: it has been a hundred years since the
first ships sailed through the Panama
Canal
in 1881 France began what would become
one of the most challenging engineering
projects ever undertaken but deceased
plagued the French workforce and up to
1/3 of workers fell ill after almost a
decade work round to a halt
the canal was sold to the US fifteen
years later the French suffered a
considerable financial loss but by the
dawn of the 20th century medical
knowledge was finally capable of
controlling outbreaks of tropical
disease the Americans opted for a new
elevated lock system which would hoist
ships above sea level upon completion
the canal had caused a massive 639
million dollars
enough to build 85 Titanic's but after
33 years of construction the canal had
claimed the lives of more than 25,000
people more than three-quarters of these
under French control
that's 500 deaths for every mile of
canal and some believe this toll to be
even higher it was a colossal
achievement a journey from the west
coast of America to Europe was caught
virtually in half and from Shanghai to
New York by 14% to foreign nations were
responsible for its construction but the
canal was finally handed over to Panama
in 1999 uniting two oceans for the first
time the canal has earned its place in
history as one of the seven wonders of
the modern world
